ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read! Jokes aside, this was my first time reading philosophical theory and I think it was a good introduction to the study of thinking as a whole.
I learned about modern critical theory on how to read, interpret, and evaluate literature.
I got to read many theory texts that were super helpful when writing analytical essays.

Learned a lot about different aspects of literary theory -- including topics of poetics, ontology, formalism, hermeneutics, Kant's critique of judgement, and more, which can be applied to so many different literary genres.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This course was useful in thinking about many broad questions, such as: how do we read? how do we understand things? what is beauty? To my knowledge, previous iterations of this class functioned as a book club of sorts, so it was interesting to look at reading from a philosophical viewpoint.
That being said, I was under the impression that this was a seminar...but he ended up lecturing most of the time, with students asking questions from time to time. The students themselves did not really have a discussion amongst themselves. Hagglund's lecture format worked here because the concepts themselves were pretty tough to make sense of by yourself, but I would have appreciated less intense theory for more discussion among students.
Additionally, a great source of stress for me this semester was the fact that the final paper is 80% --yes, 80% -- of your grade. This can be difficult because you have no way of knowing how Hagglund grades because you haven't submitted anything written that he's given feedback on. So, just keep in mind that the fate of your grade is in limbo.
There are no assignments throughout the term, which could be useful for developing our literary theorist's intuition

Prof. Hagglund was a great teacher, and the class discussion was always interesting. I think the course could use more structure, though. I would have liked to read more works of literature and maybe had assignments spaced out throughout the semester so it wasn't all riding on one final paper.
The material was fascinating, and the professor was very knowledgeable and engaging. I really enjoyed coming to class and discussing the readings with everyone.
The material was very interesting and the instructor was super engaging, but I hope we had more opportunities to receive feedback.

Strengths: the wide range of topics we covered was really insightful for someone like me who has never seriously read any philosophical texts before. If I was ever intimidated by the readings, I always found the lectures to be really clarifying-- Professor Hgglund is so great at explaining concepts concisely and giving examples grounded in real life. 

It might have been nice to have at least one other assignment factoring into our grade. Maybe a midterm paper or discussion posts? I would have been willing to do the latter since this class only meets once a week. Especially also as class time seems better used for clarifying lecture content, rather than bringing up any specific parts from the readings. It could also have been helpful to have some very general guidelines about the paper posted to canvas or emailed to us a bit earlier in the term. Since we only had that one assignment, I think that would have reminded me to start brainstorming earlier.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual Zoom meetings and provided PDFs worked well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It depends. If you are in the major, you have to take this class. If you are not a major and have not engaged with philosophical theory, you might find this class really difficult. If you are the type to really worry about your grade, this class may be really difficult because the larger chunk of your grade is a final paper.

I recommend taking it with Prof Hagglund if you have the opportunity - the syllabus changes considerably from year to year depending on who teaches. I appreciated the philosophical bent of most of our readings and discussions.
Yes, if you are a Comp Lit major you need this course.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in understanding what makes literature good from a theoretical standpoint, and how to read, analyze, and interpret texts. I feel that I gained a lot from the discussions and readings of this course.
Major requirement for lit majors -- but yes. Make sure you have enough time to do the readings in full, though. It may take longer than you expect.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
